questions.subheading: Users can sign in with their Nexus credentials and maintain single sign-on across the platform.

questions.text: Users can access their Account information using the account dropdown
questions.subheading: A user menu or dropdown in the header allows quick access to profile settings, preferences, and account management.

questions.text: Has consistent navigation patterns throughout the application
questions.subheading: Whether the main navigation is at the top of the app, in a drawer on the left-hand side, or in a hamburger menu, it is consistent. Main navigation is NOT needed on second level pages if there is a back button.

questions.text: Application settings are easily accessible to users
questions.subheading: Users can find and modify application preferences, display options, and configuration settings without difficulty.

questions.text: Help and support resources are readily available

questions.subheading: The interface adapts well to tablet screen sizes and touch interactions.
Buttons and interactive elements are appropriately sized for touch interaction.

questions.text: Uses native OS controls and patterns
questions.subheading: Follows platform-specific design guidelines and user interface conventions.
Includes proper contrast, keyboard navigation, and screen reader compatibility.
Text can be translated and displayed in different languages based on user preference.

questions.text: Provides clear and helpful error messages
questions.subheading: Error messages are informative, specific, and guide users toward resolution.

questions.text: Shows appropriate loading and progress indicators
questions.subheading: Users receive visual feedback during data loading and processing operations.
Provides helpful messaging and guidance when no data or content is available.
Collects data on how users interact with the application for improvement insights.
Tracks load times, response times, and other performance indicators.

questions.text: Has automated error reporting and logging
questions.subheading: Automatically captures and reports application errors for debugging and improvement.
Tracks which features are used most frequently to inform product decisions.
